Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Formative Research on Contacts to Gallium-Oxide for Electronic and Optoelectronic Devices

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Title: Formative Research Program on Gallium Oxide Semiconductor Materials and Interfaces to Hasten the Development of Ultra-High Efficiency Electronics

Non-Technical:
The global energy crisis presents an urgency to develop ultra-high efficiency electronics for energy conversion and transport. Electricity accounts for more than a third of primary energy consumption in the U.S., and a large portion of that electricity is handled by power electronics. For example, power electronics are required for efficient electrical switching within the electrical grid, as well as for power supplies in hybrid electric vehicles and for power converters in Naval ship platforms and to integrate renewable energy systems into the electrical grid. In each of these applications, the power semiconductor device is the critical component that determines the energy conversion efficiency, in addition to the size and cost of the system. Because of its recent material (crystal) availability and its extreme properties, gallium oxide (Ga2O3) is a novel semiconductor material that is expected to yield superior devices for ultra-high efficiency electronics. Although there is strong interest in the U.S., to date, the vast majority of research and development (R&D) on gallium oxide has been conducted in Japan. This research project is designed to hasten the development of ultra-high efficiency electronics (especially power devices) based on gallium-oxide materials and interfaces and to establish a foundation for R&D activities on gallium-oxide within the U.S. Ultimately, advances in power electronics will account for substantial gains in energy savings and an associated reduction in carbon emissions. As part of this program graduate and undergraduate students will receive training and develop professional skills needed to work in the semiconductor industry. Additional outcomes will include scientific outreach to middle and high school students and teachers, and conference sessions to inform and to help build R&D activities in this emerging field.

Technical:
Specifically, in this project researchers at Carnegie Mellon University will conduct a formative study focusing on the physics, chemistry, and processing conditions that determine the behavior of electrical contacts to doped Ga2O3 single crystal substrates and epitaxial layers. A number of devices based on Ga2O3, including Schottky diodes, MESFETs, and MOSFETs, have been demonstrated. However, as research on Ga2O3 as a wide bandgap semiconductor is in its very early stages, there is little understanding of how to control device relevant interfaces to this material. Specifically, this research will focus on (1) forming low resistivity ohmic contacts, informed by thermodynamic calculations and consideration of other physical and chemical properties, and (2) characterizing Schottky diodes for a wide range of metals on different crystal orientations of Ga2O3 and comparing the Schottky barrier heights with predicted values. Knowledge of the effects of metal workfunctions, crystal orientation, interfacial reactions, and processing conditions on the contact properties will serve as a platform to enable informed designs that device engineers can use to achieve optimized devices based on Ga2O3, and, potentially, on alloys and heterostructures of (Al,Ga,In)2O3 materials in the future.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This EAGER (Early-concepts Grant for Exploratory Research) project launched a research program on an emerging semiconductor material, gallium oxide (Ga2O3), which is targeted for ultra-high efficiency electronics and related technologies. High efficiency power electronics are increasingly needed to help address the rapid increase in the global demand for energy.  Power electronics in particular are required for efficient electrical switching within the electrical grid, for switched-mode power supplies for hybrid electric vehicles, for power conversion units that integrate renewable energy systems into the electrical grid, for power supplies for solid-state lighting, etc.  In each of these applications, the power device is the critical component that determines the energy conversion efficiency, in addition to the size and cost of the system.  Gallium oxide is predicted to be superior for use in high power devices, as evidenced by the fact that its 'power figure-of-merit' is more than 3000 times that of silicon. However, to realize the potential of gallium oxide in actual devices requires an understanding of how to process the various material layers comprising the device stack, as well as how to form suitable electrical contacts to the device structures. 

 

The intellectual merits of this research pertain to the above-mentioned challenges and can be summarized as follows. Processing conditions and electrical properties for a wide range of electrical contacts to gallium oxide were established.  The electrical performance of rectifying contacts to gallium oxide (in particular, β-Ga2O3) were found to be significantly affected by bulk or near-surface defects within the gallium oxide material; these defects often have a more dominant effect on the electrical behavior than the choice of metal contact.  As such, the results point to the need for further investigations on the types of defects that are electrically active in gallium oxide, how to prepare a more ideal surface for device structures, and the use of other crystal orientations as a platform for Ga2O3-based devices.  Our results also show that it is possible to grow metastable (alpha and epsilon) phases of gallium oxide via halide vapor phase epitaxy and that these metastable polymorphs may be advantageous for certain device structures due to their different properties (e.g., band gaps), higher crystal symmetry, and potential for forming device structures with new functionalities. The knowledge gained from these studies will serve as a platform to enable informed designs by device engineers to achieve optimized devices based on gallium oxide. Results and knowledge gained from this research were disseminated in a number of ways, including three peer-reviewed, scientific journal articles; a book chapter; and several conference presentations and seminars.

 

The broader impacts of this program include training of graduate and undergraduate students, outreach to K-12 teachers and students, and the organization of technical conference sessions on gallium oxide research.  Graduate and undergraduate students developed professional skills and received training on many semiconductor processing and device fabrication techniques, in addition to materials and device characterization techniques that are common in the semiconductor industry.  Throughout the project students worked closely with collaborators in industry to ensure the research results were pertinent to applications in the real world.  Additional outcomes included outreach to middle- and high-school students and teachers.  Examples of outreach activities included a hands-on nanotechnology session for teachers as part of CMU's "What is Research?" summer program, educational demos on materials engineering at a STEM Festival for middle- and high-school students, and undergraduate research projects. Conference sessions pertaining to new research on gallium-oxide materials and devices were also organized.  The conference sessions educated researchers about the state-of-the-art in gallium oxide materials and devices and highlighted the important challenges that need to be addressed to advance the technology.
